content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								So i randomly jumped on to see what's been goin on. gotta say, it don't hold a candle to harebrained, but, it's really solid. i thouroughly enjoyed the hour or two i put into it. this is what i was expecting to see after a year or so in develpment, after i signed on as a backer. i'm eally enthused forr what this crew have done, and eagerly await the finalized release version of  the project, and as for the half brain dead comment left by seelenschmied, durrrrr, but after a year in development you need to have more than proof of engine, it's called a business model, and i wou;d say this game was way off track from a successful model last september, it's starting to catch up, which is good considering the impending release. they've come a far piece with these last few months, and i'm thrilled. but don't go tryin' to educate me on the development process, you need a business model, and i know how slow crow funding can be, and how tedious it cn be to generate enough funding to keep a project on schedule, but that does not alleviate a responsibility to your backers, to your fans, to deliver a reasonable product in a reasonable time. to think that it does is just horrible business and leads to the destruction of the fan base that youl so desperately require for funding. glad to see they pulled their drek together and we'll finally be able to slot this thing soon. hope you guys keep kickin' up the quality. only thing i'd like to see is some sort of matchmaking service, just something to help like-minded players come together to help generate the experience they desire, i get how challenging that might be, but all in all, you guys have really got it back on track and for the dozenth time, i'm very excited for the finished product, keep knockin' it out. shoot straight, conserve ammo and, never cut a deal with a dragon.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												I have immensely enjoyed this version of shadow run.  It is a well balanced and challenging multiplayer campaign and more.   The added challenge missions were and still continue to be exciting and requires strategy and teamwork.   I love that no matter how skilled you are there still and chance for random chaos to ensue.  I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys strategy and team play.   There are several classes of characters to pick and I've played them all.  There are almost infinite ways to customize from background to training choices.  The variety of clothing items , rare drops and the ever coveted challenge mission prizes keep you coming back for more. Im looking forward to the next challenges and helping new players.

Early Access Review
								okay...after a good while i´ll edit my review, because the game has come a LONG way in the last few months... constant updates have made a fully enjoyable game out of what was a few random "test" missions last year...the devs are AWESOME,and considering their rather low budget, they got way more out of the Unity engine than i expected... I hear alot of ppl complain that it´s not "true to the pen and paper original", but i see it differently... it IS a shadowrun game, it is just another iteration of the universe... what it does, it does right...it tells a deep story, offers challenging co-op or solo round tactics missions, and what they have planned for after release sounds great, too... i burned myself alot with early access and kickstarter games, but seeing how this game developed (and keeps doing so) fills me with joy... an old shadowrun AND round based tactics fan finally gets what he always dreamed about: a good shadowrun PC game and a good tactis game in one go... looking forward to more to come :)

content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												I think this game is quite decent and actually comparing it to Harebrained Schemes series is a bit senseless (and I'm writing this after finishing all 3 shadowruns from H.S. + some user missions). Shadowrun's touch and atmosphere are definitely present here and really (like others written before me) it's really a choice between well executed X-com style game and complex RPG (H.S. series). I say - go for both, if you're a fan (like I'am). About the game, now.  It's basically simplified RPG (sometimes it's no sin at all), turn-based tactical shootout with shadowrun storyline and possible co-op - as it all stands in the game's desciption (no lying there) and that's what you're buying ;) I believe understanding this is crucial for your potential opinion on this game. Despite some minor flaws which don't spoil my fun anyhow, I appreciate quite realistic combat (where enviroment matters), in-game events, clear skills development, decent storyline and finally awesome character customization (don't tell me you did not spend first hour having fun with the character creator). I also believe players got a little to spoil ;) while most of negative opinions about this game is saying it's decent - why giving it thumbs down? And looking for minor inconsistencies with shadowrun universe - really ? Yeah, like we have dozens of shadowrun games in the market ;) Good luck with that. Travel safe in the shadows, chummers...

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												First off it is Co-Op.  Not solo like the Shadowrun Dragonfall game.  With the first intro mission being Solo and the following 4 missions being 2 player Co-Op. Later it becomes 4 player Co-Op.These missions are only playable once for the host player with max money and Karma reward.  All other players in the mission get no money and 2-3 karma it seems. Everyone gets the items that are found though in the mission so money can be got for other players that way.The game is REALLY hard and is design as a story for you to play through once with your shadowrunner.  Your toon will then be able to go onto the next campaign set of missions when they are released.  In a simular way to what Payday 2 seems to operate.Currently the Boston Lockdown Campaign consists of 32 Missions. That is all the info I am going to give ( Dont want to spoil it for you ) other than if you play them all solo you will be having to hit the forums to find out the best NPC's to take.  If you play with friends you will have a good mix of skills with fellow shadowrunners whos skills will be growing as well as yours. Plus its more fun.Solo you will have to move not only your character but also all the npc you take. If you have to babysit an NPC, the host player controls them.It's not a fast paced game, more chess like.  Think XCom with friends being able to player the other squad members when this is played Co-Op.Cons - Personally I feel there could be more to explain the setting up of your equipment and your character, letting you know that you WILL NOT be able to skill up every tree you can see. Stuff like that to stop confusion.The netcode for the game is still a little twitchy if it is busy at the hub. This will no doubt be sorted.All in all I like what I see so from from this small company and I hope that it continues to produce missions and grows.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Unfortunately, unlike SR: Dragonfall and SR: Hong Kong this game completely throws out the unique 'classes' of Shadowrun and opts instead for classes built around whatever weapon your holding.  The 'classes' in this game are called Skills: Blunt, Blades, Summoning, Spellcasting, Shotguns, Automatics, Pistols, Rigging, Hacking, Body, and Mind. The games graphics are a mixed bag.  The players and npcs are poorly rendered however the backgrounds are gorgeous.  You can customize your characters looks (and the game gives you plenty of options to pick from).  You randomly get new “loot” during missions by finding new pieces of clothing for your character to wear to further customize your appearance. There is one saving grace for SR Chronicles and that is the multiplayer component.  You can higher NPCs to go with you however they are by far weaker than players.  The game really shines when you take friends with you on the very difficult tower defense type missions that you normally have no chance at winning solo.  So far this has kept me coming back to a game that is only SR in name.I can only mourn what could have been here.  If this game used the same assets that made SR: Dragonfall/Hong Kong (Physical Adepts, etc.) AND the multiplayer aspect here then this game would be a must get.  For now, skip it unless you are willing to overlook that its only SR in spirit,  fun co-op game.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												Shadowrun Chronicles seems like one of those games you'll either love or quickly lose interest in, depending on your preferences. I wager the 270 hours I have clocked in so far firmly place me in the former camp, though.SRC is essentially a turn-based squad tactics game with multiplayer support. If you enjoyed combat in XCOM, Jagged Alliance or similar games, you should be able to have fun with this one as well. Unlike these other titles, however, SRC has a stronger RPG factor in that you are "closer" to the Shadowrunner you create, and usually only control this one character, unless you skip on the whole social part that makes this game stand out and play exclusively with NPCs in your team.Combat itself is easy to learn whilst still challenging the player with tough encounters, some of whom may require multiple attempts. The absence of unlimited healing a la Shadowrun Returns' mages prevents fights from turning into wars of attrition, instead rewarding quick manoeuvers with clever use of cover. Notably, there is no Overwatch/Interrupt due to the developer's reasoning of such actions penalizing movement and melee combat too much. This is a game where (generally) you aren't supposed to hunker down and keep shooting, but instead to try to get close and flank the enemy.The level designers' attention to detail deserves a special shout-out, for whilst the environment is not truly destructible, just about any furniture can and will get damaged in a fight. Windows burst, computers get wrecked, vending machines spill their drinks, and fire extinguishers spill white clouds of CO2 as they are damaged, which adds a lot to the immersion as your team kicks some corporate hoop. The visuals as well as the (all-voiced) dialogue truly manage to convey the cyberpunk atmosphere of Shadowrun, evoking the right feelings of this world.Another notable and RPG-like feature is the customization, which is setting a new bar for this subgenre. Albeit not quite covering everything you could ask for (stances, different faces and recoloring would be nice to have), the amount of clothes you can combine and wear is massive, easily allowing you to create a truly unique Runner. And you can bet that you will see some truly weird people hanging out in the hub, as dress-up games have become almost a community minigame by now.Unfortunately, there isn't much going on in terms of roleplaying, as the game does not fully support such activity yet. Social areas like clubs were a feature planned for some time after release, but with the studio being in financial troubles it remains to be seen just when they get around to adding this. Private chat channels as well as private messaging are other features badly needed, but in theory you can at least RP with your team when attempting a mission.Right now, the only endgame is a rather grindy "challenge" that does not quite manage to capitalize on the game's strengths but at least gives people something to do. Personally, I'd rather recommend rolling up another character, as even multiple campaign playthroughs remain fun thanks to the base mechanics. Though the studio is currently having a tough time staying afloat, they are still working on new content and have recently announced plans for an expansion. Lack of an SRR-style editor is a shame, but no deal breaker.In summary, whilst this may not be a perfect Shadowrun game, it absolutely manages to be an enjoyable one. Of note, I also don't believe Shadowrun Returns was a perfect SR game. To me, the perfect Shadowrun game would be something in-between SRC and SRR. But if you enjoyed Returns, give Chronicles a look, too, as I feel it simply approaches this perfection from the other angle.tl;dr:+ solid turn-based tactical squad combat, difficult but not unfairly so+ incredibly fun in co-op with a friendly playerbase+ awesome character customization+ nicely catches the dystopian atmosphere of the Shadowrun setting- desperately needs some Quality-of-Life improvements (private messaging)- no level adjustment means endgame runners invited to low level missions will trivialize them- sadly no level editor like in Shadowrun Returns

												Feels like a poor man's Xcom in Shadowrun setting. So if you here for a story and RPG, play Shadowrun Returns, Dragonfall and Hong Kong instead. If you are here for a tactical strategy, play XCOM or Invisible, Inc.What's even worse, Shadowrun Chronicles tries to be an MMO, but offers nothing except friend lists and coop, while still requiring you to be connected to the game server. So if it's down for any reason, you can't play the game. The upside is that it's not really worth playing (unless you are a huge fan of Shadowrun and completed all games by Harebrained Schemes).

												Shadowrun Chronicles - Boston Lockdown, how should I say it... It is simply a masterpiece, no other game is able to compare to its monumentally amazing aspects. Firstly, it boast a fanastical system from which you are capable of customising your character to fit your preference. As well as this, the gameplay features much to be enjoyed as it has a very pleasing skill system which has been simplified to be fitting for anyone who wants to get straight into the action. The missions are not groundbreaking although they do provide a lot of amusement especially with the game's integrated co-op mechanic, making it fun for the entire family. Sound design on components such as weapons and actions are favourable and suitable as for the voice acting, "wew lad"."Overall I would rate it a 3/5" - Mojang

content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												Imagine you can play Left 4 Dead turn-based, Able to upgrade your character with more skills and weapons? That't what SC:BL is about. No usual MMORPG stuff like grinding, stupid repetitive quests: just raids in all its glorious beauty. Team up with 3 random dudes, and go for it! 1 quest if you feel hasten; 10 quests if you have your time! Each quest takes 15-20 minutes of your real time, so you can plane in advance.Co-op it the greatest feature of the game for me. I always liked co-op board games like Pandemic, Arkham Horror, Battlestar Galactica, Shadows Over Camelot etc. I don't know about PvP (which is yet to come), but Co-op is just great and that is exactly why you should buy the game. There is some content yet to come, but for me it is already a masterpiece.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												I've had extensive experience throughout the development of this game, having bought it the minute it showed up on steam and played throughout the early access/beta process. For me this is a very fun game to hop on and do a few runs with friends and then hop off again. Its very much a casual game. It catches the feel of classic turn based combat very well in my opinion. Yes, it does not have things like overwatch or take cover/hunker down. According to the developers at one point they claimed that was intentional, and in truth any X-Com player knows that overwatch in particular is very easy to exploit so its understandable. Its important to understand that though this is Shadowrun flavored and certainly catches the spirit of Shadowrun, that it is NOT Shadowrun ruleset. Things like skills and cyberware/essence are handled very differently in this game. Don't let that scare you though as the system they do use will still seam very familiar and it doesn't detract from the title for anyone but the most hardened Shadowrun purists. To me the thing that most lets the game down right now is the chat system. Its SUPER basic and lacks things like the ability to PM other players, ignore people, or even just switch it off. The group chat is fairly buggy and overall its something that in a social game I would hope is a priority for them to improve apon. I'd also like to see some kind of queue system for quick joining in runs which would only improve on the "hop in and have a run" feel the game projects. Another negative for me is the voice acting. The main characters voice (for females anyways) is HORRIBLE. The accent and the acting. I get that its supposed to be a game set in Boston so credits for trying with the heavy Boston accent but its horrible to listen to on a daily basis especially with a nasally tone to it. Another thing I don't like is the fact that the story voice over takes into no account your skills, so if for example you play a decker you still get voice over of your character moronically not knowing what a grid access point was. On a positive note I can't say enough about the character customization in this game. I loath to draw a parallel back to X-com but again it has that kind of depth of customization and honestly even shames many true "MMOs" in its ability to let you get your character looking unique and like you want it. Even this however is a bit let down to me by the limited number of character portraits so though you can make an amazing character sprite, the portrait for it will be cookie cutter and almost never match the character. Still as a launching point for a future series of modules and gameplay Shadowrun Chronicles is an excellent way to integrate multiplayer and the Shadowrun experience while maintaining a familiar style to the other Shadowun games and good turn based experience. I'd certainly recommend it to people, both fans of Shadowrun and people just looking for a casual, quick fun experience.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												---1 MAY UPDATE---New idea for implementation ...- Characters need some sort of rating scheme (like a "level") to make it easier to group with others of equivalent ability. Right now people are advertising themselves in chat as "Decker LFG, 4 Hacking, 3 Automatics". That's way too clunky. Should be able to say something as simple as, "Lvl 4 Decker LFG". Or maybe give characters a Karma rating so they can use it to identify their "level" more easily.---LAUNCH DAY UPDATE---I made some changes to my "April Update" below. I'm very much enjoying the game, but as I've been playing some things have come to mind that I would like to see implemented.---APRIL 2015 UPDATE---A lot of updates occurred in April. The game is starting to look like a cross between Shadowrun Returns (SRR) and XCOM. Fans of the PNP RPG might be disappointed in the character creation process as it is not a literal translation of those rules. At this time there are no traditional PNP attributes like strength, intelligence, etc. They are reflected instead in broader categories such as Body (which encompasses health, strength, and dexterity), which is labeled as a "skill" along with traditional skills such as Blades, Pistols, Automatics, etc. As you spend karma in a skill set (I'll use Body as an example) you have to make decisions at each purchasing point whether you want to increase your health or dexterity, dexterity or accuracy, health or reaction time, etc. I'm not in love with this method, because I'm one of those who would have preferred to see a literal translation of the PNP rules. However, I understand the realities of creating a game, and I understand that compromises have to be made based on aesthetics and resource limitations. Harebrained Schemes had a significantly larger budget to make every iteration of SRR, and even Jordan Weisman (the creator of the Shadowrun IP) decided to alter their approach in making SRR because the PC game version did not need all the elements of the PNP rules to be a good game. Cliffhanger has taken a similar approach with Shadowrun Chronicles (SRC), and while it might serve as a turn-off to diehard fans of the PNP game, frankly all those differences are forgotten once you start a mission. Once inside, one's only care is completing the run and getting out alive.A few things I'd like to see that are not (yet?) in the game:- Matrix, but I'm sure it's coming. Right now all cyber actions occur in Augmented Reality (AR).- More character slots ... three is not enough for the variety of character choices!  -- As a KS backer, I got an additional 2 upon launch. Or does everyone have 5 now?- Rifles (right now they only have pistols, shotguns, and automatics)- A larger hub. It's already obvious to me that the hub is going to be very crowded.- A place to buy Doc Wagon contracts in the hub! Maybe this appears later in the game, but I see no reason it should not be included from the start.- Secondary weapons for NPC runners. They need a go-to when they are out of ammo. Players carry them, so NPCs should have them too.- More weapons, cyber gear, and cosmetic items for sale, or at least visible, from vendors  -- They are in the game, but you can't see them until you progress in "level", then they start showing up at vendors. Still, it would be nice to see the assortment of vendor weapons even if they can't be purchased yet.- Unarmed combat (there is no skill tree for it)- An item to revive fallen runners during a mission- Ability to shoot-move, in that order. At present, standard actions such as attacks end the character's turn, and according to an in-game tooltip, that's intentional so it's unlikely to change. Still, if you can make two actions during a turn, I don't see why choosing to shoot first should deny you the second action.- More carrying capacity. Hired Runners have no tactical items, so they can't carry medkits, grenades, etc. That means the only person who can act as a medic is the player, but players can't carry enough medkits to treat everybody. Possible solutions are, 1) give players the ability to equip hired runners with tactical items (that are returned at end of mission if not used), 2) significantly increase player character carrying capacity (ability to carry a minimum of 4 items), or 3) increase the number of times a medkit can be used.---MARCH 2015 REVIEW---My complete opinion is still TBD, but for now I'm voting this "up" to balance against the knuckleheads who voted it down because it didn't fit their definition of a MMO.I backed this project when it first became available on Kickstarter under the name Shadowrun Online. Yes, the devs referred to it as a MMO, but ***if the complainers had actually paused to read the description of the game*** instead of throwing thier money into it because it contained the words "Shadowrun Online" and "MMO", they would have known it was ***always*** marketed as a turn-based co-op game. Seriously, go back to the original Kickstarter announcement and read what it says. At no time did the devs ever mislead anyone about what they wanted to make. So anyone who is disgruntled or disappointed because they didn't get the WoW-like MMO they wanted has no room to complain. But of course, that won't stop them.As for the state of the game, it is coming along nicely ... but aside from the fancier graphics I haven't seen anything yet that really makes it stand out from Shadowrun Returns (SRR). I have faith the devs will continue to improve it since this project was for them as much a labor of love as a business venture. But as of March 2015, the only significant difference between Chronicles and Returns is that Chronicles offers community interaction and co-op play which SRR is lacking.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												Updated for Final Release.Finally making its way through Early Access, a name change and several updates. Shadowrun Chronicles is now complete and handing out the nuyen and contracts like a mad Johnson. I am happy to say that the developers have finally brought this game to state that I can enjoy. Delivering a full game experience. With the ability to create a unique runner, skill sets, and up to 4 player co-op. Now while there is plenty of that has been improved and even fixed. There is still some areas that need a bit of shining. However that doesn't stop this from being a very enjoyable title. Using your crafted runner you will bring something unique to the mission. Rather that be guns, hacking, or maybe a little magic. The story of SRC is not as in-depth as its compatriots. Being mostly linear and devoid of RPG elements. The graphics are good enough, as is the aesthetic of cyberpunk. Although the zoom features lets you see the block like shapes of the characters. In all SRC is a game that Shadowrun fans can enjoy and includes a pivotal element that other Shadowrun games missed. Multiplayer. For this reason and more. You should check out Shadowrun Chronicles - Boston Lockdown I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!


YouTube™ Video: Indie Game of the Week - Shadowrun Chronicles - Boston Lockdown 

			Views: 291		

			Finally making its way through Early Access, a name change and several updates. Shadowrun Chronicles is now complete and handing out the nuyen and contracts like a mad Johnson.		

I hope you enjoy!Martyr

content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												Shadowrun Chronicles is a fun tactical RPG. Note: this review is mostly relevant for the campaign. I haven't touched the end-game content yet.Currently the game works best in Single Player. Most of the current player-base have end-game level characters, so playing pick-up Co-Op will make the missions way too easy. If you are playing with a friend of similar level, then Co-Op would be fantastic, but I haven't been able to try that.The game plays like a simplified version of Shadowrun Returns, with elements of X-Com. Its not much of an RPG (no exploration, no branching dialog) but you do control one character through the campaign and can choose a progression and item selection. If you play alone, you bring along 3 other NPCs with you on missions. They level up automatically and it doesn't matter if they die.This game is good if you like Shadowrun, and want something to play after having beaten all of HBS games. Most missions are under 30 minutes in length, so its a great game to play if you are short on time.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												Perfect game for those that would enjoy a strong COOP experience.Saddly the game mechanics are completely different then those of the Hairbrain Studio Shadowrun Series Mechanics. - But all in all I keep wanting to play with real players in the story line more then with just the Henchmen you can hire.Saddly I can't justify getting this game at full price for the Delux version simply because I got it at discount price through a HumbleBundle sale for less then $20 Dollars and for all its flaws was seemed just right for the cost. - besides a portion of the money went to a charity in the process.Any who back on topic.As you can see from the video trailer and the screen shots on the store page the game looks interesting.Pro's- Can further Customize and cordinate your character wardrobe, once you collect the clothing during missions.- 4 player COOP for the story and Challenges- can be solo played- Enjoyable with friends.Con's- Plenty of miss clicks have caused many miss-haps during combat - - Player deselects weapon during combat and uses previously selected weapon/skill to engage enemy - - Player if still has movement points can be accidently moved from cover into open ending turn with character moving to the action bar area where your weapon's and skills are located- During COOP other players have to communicate through Text instead of a HUD display to assist in other players Cordinating with one another for targeting a single enemy in a crowded room can be troublesome.- I collected around 48 pairs of Buckle Pants and I don't have any way to sell them or get rid of or sell the random loot in the outfit menu selections.All in all I enjoyed the gaming experience with my friends and look forward to the next chapter installement for the story once its released.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												Pros:- Solid co-op x-com combat (the only place I have found that strategy system in a co-op environment).- Solid graphics (although not ground breaking some of the maps are just amazing, better than x-com, and the detail such as exploding windows in such is nice.)- BEST community! ( only have about 17hrs at the time of writing this but EVERYONE I have run into in game has been nice and helpful. Alot even rollplay in chat during games, which adds to the environment). - Shadowrun co-opCons: - Its all about the combat (nothing else really takes place in this game, no side hacking like in other shadowrun titles. No talking your way out of situations like in the Hairbrain games, every mission is kick drek and take names. Possible a Pro for some people but I have noticed alot of complaining in forums about its lack of deversity).- map variety (although as stated the map are amazing, having not completed the campaign I am already seeing repeated maps in storymode).- Chat system is lacking (for a multiplayer game that requires grouping you can't whisper/tell people or even those on your friend list!)- Singleplayer lacking (you have the ability to play the story singleplayer and multiplayer but the companions for singleplayer are lacking compared to other players making it difficult to solo and forcing people to play multiplayer). Overall it doesn't follow Shadowrun PnP to much and it isn't one of the Hairbraine games so I think alot of people got down on it. However it is a great multiplayer x-com style co-op game that I am now sure I will be getting my return on in fun.

												The game is fun and it has potential. However I can't say that I'd recommend this game to someone. The balancing of the game nerfs the team cannot have rigger and other summoners on the same team, cannot deploy multiple riggers. Theres a lack of bad guys you fight most of them are simple gunners. Next is the lack of ability to revive a teammate, a teammate goes down and you have 5 turns to finish the mission and escape. This is not how shadowrunners work in the RPG a guy goes down you get the job done regarudless. There also seems to be a lack of ability to revive a someone after they go down. Medkits or the basic ability to heal you or yourteam mates have to be found and your limited to 2 of them per run. I'd rather a weight system, I can only carry two medkits but I have cybernetic limbs... which is silly. I think if they work on the balancing it could be a lot of fun. Yes 4 riggers could swarm a map, so put the ability to hack drones in so they loose the drones.. you swarm with 4 riggers and your going to be in a world of hurt.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												I'm haapy with how this game turned out. It's different from the single-player shadowrun game. It feels like the devs are committed and I am quite enjoying the experience.Pros: - the campaign is nice and long- skill trees: while I wouldn't say no to more options, there are quite a few nodes and you can always take a few picks out of trees that are not your primary/secondary to pick up some goodies- good atmosphere - it feels shadowrunny- the game is mostly voiced- The launch was plagued with serious, debilitating lag. But the devs response to the lag was very good - communication on what they were doing, how their troubleshooting was going, and appoligies. The lag is now gone.Cons:- there aren't many differet types of gear, and what gear exists is pretty easy to get ahold of. I haven't had to wait on gear from a nuyen standpoint in a long time, I just have to wait for it to unlock in the shops and instantly buy it. I wish there were more gear and that you could see available before being able to afford it. Also, there are some extreme dry spells - I've gone a dozen missions in a stretch without having access to any new gear.- the voice acting is heavily-accented Bostonite. It is a seriously unpleasant accent (think hyper-aggressive baby talk). I get that the game takes place in Boston, but there's no reason to pick the most heavily-accented voices. I'd much rather be able to listen to the dialog without cringing. Also in the voice acting domain, there is a moaner in medical settings that is particularly irritating. You'll hear it - it's someone moaning like a fire engine siren. It's weird and off-putting.- the tooltips when choosing skills from the skill trees are pretty light on information. This makes it difficult to make an informed decision about which option to choose at branches. There is no karma reset, so once you make your choice, you don't get to go back and try the other option. This will be easier once the wikis start filling up with info.TL;DR: It's a solid game, with committed devs. If you're into Shadowrun, pick it up :o)

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												I am really enjoying Shadowrun Chronicles. It takes the standard Shadowrun series gameplay (SR Returns, DragonFall, Hong Kong etc.) and simplifies it down, then makes it multiplayer. I would really go as far as to say, while being one of the most simple Shadowrun games mechanic wise I feel like the addition of multiplayer and extra character customization with the large amount of player cosmetic options really goes a long way all on its own. Even if you are not really interested in playing cooperatively with other players on your shadowrun team, you can still play through the missions with a team of AI shadow runners of your choice. To go into more details about how skills work in Shadowrun chronicles, each weapon type has its own skill "helix" Two separate paths that you make choices from, each level unlocking a skill from either the top or bottom path. There are no "classes" in Chronicles, but your skills are determined by your weapon choices. Each skill set is different, as an example guns are broken down into types, pistol, assault rifle, shotgun etc. while magic, summoning, rigging, and decking are all on separate trees. There are also Paths for Mind/Body that deal with passive abilities that can benefit any weapon choice/ play style. Most player interaction takes place in a hub area in downtown Boston, where in between missions you will meet other shadowrunners, stock up on supplies, sell and buy new gear, pick up side missions or simply change your wardrobe. There is not a whole lot to it other than that, The campaign Boston Lockdown also is centered around the characters you meet here, and as you progress the main plot the hub world changes a little at a time. Story wise I have been entertained well and am enjoying the plot, even if it feels a little shallow and lacks player choice almost completely. There is a strong feeling of mystery around the events that unfold during the main plot and I cant wait to play more.Overall I recommend Shadowrun Chronicles to any fans looking for another Shadowrun game to play, or to anyone looking for an Isometric RPG they can play Co-op.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												This game had quite a rough start, but it's definitly worth the wait. As an avid SR Pen&Paper player, I really love the setting and tone this game has. The world, the slang, the style - they capture the feeling of the sourcebooks just perfect.One question I hear quite often is if this game is related to Harebrained Schemes SR:Returns and Dragonfall and what the differences are. First of all: All three games are great (Finished both HBS games, pledged the third on KS and currently playing SR:Chronicles), but they are made by two different companies. So, apart from the world and lore, they are not related in any way.Both use a turn based XCOM style combat system as a core concept. HBS games are much more text heavy, while SR:Chronicles has full voiceacting and less text.Due to the Multiplayer character of SR:C, its playing much faster than the single player HBS games. I really love the community in this game, the chats are full of people who know and love the lore and even speak in the slang. It's a little bit like playing on a RPG Server.The inventory and weapons system looks much larger than HBS system.One thing I personally love ist the fact that equipment does not alter your characters appearance. You can change the style of your character at any time in the hub for free. And the list with clothing, tattos, shoes and more is quite impressive.One thing I really miss is the matrix. You have short moments in matrix nodes as hubs, but there is no "combat matrix" like in HBS games. I hope Cliffhanger will develop something similar for future campaigns.So, if you like quick, action packed runs with a good community, play this game.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												Keep playing.That's the basic advice I have for this game. Look beyond the initial missions. Look beyond the poor graphics in the hub, or in general. Look beyond the voice-acting.Just keep playing. You'll see why soon enough. The game itself is actually superb, be it the mission design, the storyline, the overall RPG system... it's good stuff, thoroughly enjoyable now that the server-side issues are dealt with.And you can pretty much play it by yourself with NPC parties, if that's what you want. This is *not* a game that forced me to group with people to progress, or to see content. It's a game that can be played by yourself or with others, and it's a worthy start to what can be much, much more if expanded upon.So keep playing. You'll thank me later.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												Having put a fair bit of time into the game on multiple characters, I've seen a few of the ups and downs SRC has had to handle and to be frank?  For what it is, it's a good game.  Now, I'd like to preface that with the statement that I've been following this game since it was announced some years ago, back when it was still called Shadowrun Online, when all the game really had to offer were a handful of unpolished missions and character options.  That said, it has come leaps and bounds in what can honestly be called a particularly ambitious project for a small studio like Cliffhanger, and you know what, I think they did a pretty good job all things considered.Admittedly, they have had some stumbling blocks, from early launch lag issues to missing or broken items and even in some cases surprise gamebreaking bugs, but through all that their Dev team was very responsive to the community's questions and concerns and tried to maintain as much transparency as they could concerning their efforts to fix said issues.  Even after the fact, they tried to make reparations to to the community as a whole as an apology for the trouble, which, in my opinion, speaks very highly of Cliffhanger as a whole.That said, and onto the game itself, its a hex grid, turn based isometric centered in the Shadowrun universe following the adventures of your shadowrunner through (for the sake of being spoiler-free) the events of what could be called the Boston Incident.The story itself is creative and unique, and well written besides, with tolerable voice acting where it applies (though the Boston accent can get tiresome during subsequent playthroughs) and does stay loyal to the Shadowrun source material.  That said, and I can't emphasize this enough, the game is not a point-for-point match to the PnP source.  Certain liberties have been taken in regards to the game being both online and, well, being a game.  Certain facets in the PnP source are unfortunately absent, in as far as customization goes, and as of right now most missions center around a run-and-gun playstyle (meaning that no, there isn't a stealth option).  That said, what it delivers, it delivers very well in that the combat is well-polished, balanced, and fun, and the downtime inbetween missions does offer a lot of chance for backstory, worldbuilding, and customization.Bear in mind, what I said about the game lacking certain aspects of customization doesn't mean that the game lacks in customization at all.  In fact, it offers a wide array of options, both practical and cosmetic, both at creation and that which can be earned through gameplay.  This includes items that can be used in missions, weapons, armor, various types of cybernetics and spells, and a wide array of skills and abilities.  It opens up a lot of tactical options and allows players to approach objectives from several angles, which, in some cases, is absolutely vital towards the success of any given mission.Difficulty can vary from build to build, and while there's no expressly "right" way to play, there is a certain limitation to the number of playstyles you can use.  That said, there are a lot of variations, so the limits to what you can do are pretty broadly defined.The interface is fine for the format.  There aren't any outstanding bugs or issues at this iteration of the game and for the most part, it's very intuitive and easy to master.  Gameplay is in tradition turn-based format, and despite the game being online, it can be played in both single and multiplayer, both of which offer their own share of advantages and disadvantages.  That said, while the game is beatable in purely solo play, it is *significantly* harder to finish the content.  Harder, but not impossible.Ultimately it delivers what it promised.  I bought the delux edition when it came out and you know what?  As far as games go, I got my money's worth.  It had it's ups and downs, and while I really don't think the Early Access reviews give the game a fair shake at what it is now, compared to what it was, they do have offer a good look into what the game was like during developement.  Is it worth 30$?  I think so.  I go my money's worth, which is a lot more than I can say for a lot of AAA titles in the last few years.  Better for it that you don't really need a background in the Shadowrun universe in order to enjoy the content for what it is.So for me at least, I give the game a solid 4 out of 5 and with it my recommendation.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												I'd give it sideways thumbs if I could.  I like the game but I don't love it.  The following is from the perspective of playing it solo.  If you intend to play it co-op, I'd easily recommend this game.-Can't disable the multiplayer features. Namely, I keep clicking on the chat even though I want nothing to do with the chat.-Can't overwatch/guard your characters.-Can't save/load. Granted, each map is pretty small but you have to roll with the punches. If things go sideways, you might as well "leave mission" and start over from the area start.-I had money, I needed a better weapon, but none were available. For quite a while, the hired runners had better arms and armor than me. It's frustrating being the weakest link and there's nothing you can do about it until the story advances to a point it unlocks more store content.-Continuation of above: no options to adjust difficulty. There are some missions that appear to be unbalanced (like this one where I was attacked on two fronts and they were coming faster than I could kill them; finally completed it on my third or fourth attempted).-Unlike Harebrained Schemes titles, there's really only one mission I've seen that you can get through without fighting. Ehm, dialogs are linear and the story doesn't appear to branch at all.-There's some character development but it is shallow compared to the Harebrained Schemes versions.

												I'm finding the game gets blasted with a lot of undeserved hate on these reviews. If you were looking for a 'true' MMO; you'll be sorely dissapointed.This game isn't, and I don't have the impression that it tries to be.It's more of a ... turn based Borderlands. Grab 3 friends and go to town.The plot is forgettable, and conversation between me and my friends tends to go something akin to 'Why are we trying to shoot fat orc lady again?' - 'I dunno, it's the ojective. Can you mark her so I can salvo, or should I take a potshot'? - 'I need to resummon a drone, but let the hacker mark if you need it!' aaaaand we're back off to gamespeek.It's pretty unique on the market in that sense, it's a co-op turn based game that you can play with 4 people; but will have no problem playing with just 2 or 3 thanks to the henchman system.Don't expect a full fledged MMO going in, grab a few friends who share your love for turn-based and go to town, you'll enjoy it.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
												At its original full price it certainly wasn't worth getting. But it got a reduction and now it's available for almost nothing in a Humble Bundle. First off, and the reason it has done badly, it's NOT what you would expect from a Shadowrun game after having played the HBS offerings. There is far less depth to story elements, there is no overwatch mechanic and hacking, lockpicking etc is reduced to clicking on your target and a seccess or fail roll. Missions are taken from a single central "market" hub contributing to its not being great in an RPG sense.All this said, it has a lot of positives as well and is certainly enjoyable purely as a TBS more geared towards co-op fun. You can play it fine as a single player game but it quickly becomes clear that this isn't where the main fun lies. My advice is to get it in its Humble package and only grab the DLCs if you find it's to your liking. Overall though it's a perfectly good tbs based in the Shadowrun world and quite unique in that it offers tbs co-op. It's really not the pig Shadowrun fans have made it out to be and despite its faults I'm going to give it a thumbs up overall. As long as you approach it "eyes open" that it's not like the other shadowrun games then you should enjoy it.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												This is an awesome adaptation of Shadowrun. Really lots and lots of options for dressing up your character exactly how you want him to look. Trannie trolls, dapper elves, you name it.Game systems are fun, non-linear progression trees with hard choices and party combo set ups. It's a turn based game best played with 2-4 players, and turns are simultaneous which makes the turns go fast. You can play it solo, and it's fun then, but more so with other people.It's X-com meets Jagged Alliance that you can play with your friends.There is no pvp yet, it's all co-op, but the developers promise a pvp mode in future updates.As to my very own 3 star rating: it has swords, it has elves, and promises to have pvp in the future. I give it 2.5 stars out of 3. :)P.S. First shadowrun computer game where making a character was a fun experience.P.P.S. First week had some server-side input lag and a lot of reviews bash this game based on that. They fixed the problem. No input lag now. Come on in, the water is fine.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												AS a fan of Shadowrun, i'm sad to say i can't recommend this game....First of all, the story: hem...well...it was...well see....THE character doing, hmmm, stuff like retrieve data, find something, obtain intel WITH is Drekking gun! always! no speaking, no roleplay, just a mindless "tactical" shooter. and even for the tactical part, the game miss the most important features: the overwatch. and, by the way, they're no story AT ALL!My character just bump in the hub with the speak to those guy and yay, let's shoot something -_-'So, if chronicles mean not solid story, it's ok. (strangely, i always think a chonicles was a kind of long story...)second thing: yes,  i've only play 2 hours. Guess why? c'mon, try it, it's fun!no? no one guess? even you, in the last row? it was bacause each time i try to play to this game, the server got down. It's not even a joke, i try to play, BAM, "update" i wait and connect myself 1 hour after....lag...more lag...server down....I don't want to be a crybaby, but i've buy this game in the state of mind to play with, not just stare at the title in my steam library (what i do, finally, pretty sad huh?)third: the character creation: so let see: choose a metahuman race: check! noteable difference betwenn? nope.rp backstory: yup. two line, three maximum. never use after that in the game, for what i could see.clothing: yay, "lot" of choice. impact on the game: nope.weapon: yup, one of each for the beginning.(then you been throw in the hub after a tutorial mission with the less creative thing i've seen in a videogame: you wake up, confusing, without any idea of where you are.....i mean, c'mon guys, the "oblivious" character background was so used, and missused, and re-used again....it's even not a good starting point for a scenario (and, after playing pen and paper rpg, it's the most common trick made by lazy people writing,  playing or mastering games!!!)did i miss something? oh, yes, my favorite part: tactical ! i've brievly write above the overwatch, but it's not the worse.the worse is when you realize whatever you do, or don't do, the enemy will come point blank, for the most part when you pinned down by a sentry turret. And, for some, like the bargesth, they cause fear, meaning you will go running out of your cover. Of course, you could shoot those mob before and...in fact no, you can't, because they're pop out of blue!for the end, the multiplayer aspect of the game: i've not try it, first of all because of the connectivity wich i mentionned before, and, actually, that don't really interest me much. I like to play solo, for discovering the story ....oh, wait, the game haven't one...maybe i will try, one day then...in short: if you like Shadowrun, do you favor: don't spend your money in this game. not now. maybe when the game was in full release, but now it's more an pre-release alpha, after the alpha and beta, if you see my point.Try, if you want a good story, Shadowrun returns and/or Dragonfall director's cut. Even the Infamous Microsoft Shadowrun / clone of CS/ not even a story/it's a FPS? game was funnier to play.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												UpdateLag has been reduced to normal levels, and there are far fewer connection difficulties. I have since encountered different issues, such as the weapon vendor having a blank screen no matter how many times I restart so that I can no longer progress my character's weapons. Now that I've gotten a chance to play the game I'm disappointed that the only benefit I get from being a hacker, or a lockpicker is the chance to get an extra pair of pants or a skimpy bikini. I started a couple of other characters as well, but there is very little variation between the them. Hackers are essentially crappy ranged attackers with a couple of stun abilities. Gameplay is still very much like other negative reviewers have described it, you'll fall asleep if you don't have a friend goading you into playing and keeping it lively. The best Shadowrun game is still on a cardtridge or a piece of paper, and maybe if gamers stop defending every piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥cashgrab that caters to their interests you'll get a quality game someday.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~This is the current experience.*TRY* to log into or create a character, this might cause the connection to hang requiring any number of restarts. Some of your characters might be lost to you for hours on end.Connect to your friend, sometimes spending hours wondering why your friend in the same room can't find your instance or mission lobby. When the server manages to find someone, it will still take forever while the connection hangs. During any of the loading processes, you may have to shut down the character and repeat the hellish login process.Once you're in a mission, expect 2-60 seconds to have every single action recognized and processed by the server. Turns that should take 10 seconds will take 3 minutes. The sync time between players will be radically different, so don't expect your horrible experience to be equal. During loading times, watch the same worthless human filth or games journalists that recommended this game on Steam explain that 'this is normal' on an annoying general chat, because even though this is a bad single player game with awful multiplayer options, it was retooled from an even worse mmo. Although not long enough to have the benefit of a persistent world, or  a group-finding system other than spamming the general chat with "LFG", "DID YOU INVITE ME?", "SORRY I COULDN'T ACCEPT THE INVITE BECAUSE MY GAME CRASHED TEN TIMES".The game itself is undeniably shallow but approaching mediocrity WITH a coop partner, and I won't waste any more time than that explaining it because you simply should not be buying this game.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
IntroductionShadowrun Chronicles: Boston Lockdown is a turn-based tactical game that has a similar battling system to XCOM. It's part of the Shadowrun series, but doesn't really seem to fit in with the other games that where mad ein thsi series. It has it's good and bad points, one of the main points being the new 4 multiplayer co-op mode that adds a bit more depth to the game itself from the other games in the series.GameplayShadowrun Chronicles: Boston Lockdown starts with a really nice character design screen. ou are able to design your character, it has a large variety of tools that you can use to make your character unique and what you want yiur character to look like. Unfortuantly, this customization isn't carried over to the AI that are with you, letting the game down a little bit, but not by all that much. It would've been nice to be able to fully be able to customize your entire team, but it's not possible in this game. The missions do start off rather well, you might get a feeling that you are playing in XCOM, but with a cyberpunk feel and many different characters. Although to start off with the missions seem to be nice and flexible, it does start to get that feeling of just being the same mission, but with a different location that you are in and different enemies that you have to kill. The weapons that you can equip on your character seem to be all nice, and they all seem to be different from one anther. But in actual fact all the weapons that you find aren't really all that great, you don't really get that satifaction when you find a weapon in this game. I would say that playing co-op with some friends on this game would definatley be recommened, just because your friends will probably bring along useful items and equipment rather than the AI. It also makes it run a lot faster than having to play single player with the AI running with you as well.The graphics of the game are great, and what really helps the game pull itself back up from some of the negative things that I have listed above. The graphics of each area that you go into seem different from the last and gives you a new change of scenery throughout the game. The lighting and shadowing isn't really focused upon that much throught the game, but some points here and there did stand out to be rather nice looking and such.Pros+ Fun Cooperative play+ Great character customization+ Nice Graphics+ Trading Cards & AchievementsCons- Samey sort of missions- Not fully customizable squadResult / Final thoughtsShadowrun Chronicles - Boston Lockdown is a fairly fun and enjoyable game. I would recommend playing it in short bursts of say 30 minutes - 1 hour, as you may get bored of the samey missions and not come back to the game. The graphics are well designed and the character customization is well done.For more reviews on a wide range of games, go and follow Sometimes You Playing curator group here.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												This is a good game.  The people complaining it's not strategic enough either have not played very far, or want it to be an exact clone of X-Com.  Although there's no overwatch button that you're forced to press about 1000 times per mission, it has it's own mechanics that make it interesting.  The game's storyline is not going to win any awards, but by the end I did want to know what would happen.  You can also click past all the dialogue if you choose to.  Shadowrun fans will be surprised to learn that Decking now does damage in the meat space.  However, after some thought, this makes sense both for gameplay and for lore purposes.  Throughout the game, the story seems to assume that datajacks now wireless and that every metahuman has one, two assumptions that would have been far-fetched in 1980s, but are obvious to today's cell phone culture.  Since wireless networks are inherently capable of peer-to-peer connections, I think it's actually logical that IC damage could happen even without connecting to the (server-based) matrix.  Of course, from a gameplay perspective, standing around while the team's decker entered the matrix would be pretty boring, so the changes are also necessary to make Shadowrun multiplayer.  For those who prefer single player experience: My Rifle/Decker character was able to complete the entire main story and all side missions with no grouping; only the post-game challenge mission requires grouping.  Some missions were a little tough, so there are probably some character builds that would require grouping for the main game.  For first time players: You will have enough experience points, money, and weapon slots to choose two of the main damage ability trees: Shotguns, Handguns, Automatics, Blades, Blunt, Spellcasting, Summoning, Decking (Hacking), or Rigging (using robotic drones).  For those learning the game, I recommend you choose Automatics or Shotguns for one of your two skills, and whatever you want for the second.  You could also pair Hacking with Spellcasting or Summoning, or Rigging with Spellcasting.  Don't pick both melee skills, both magic skills, or both minion skills (Rigging and Summoning), at least until you know what you're doing.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												UPDATE: I cannot recommend this game since it is Abandonware currently. The devs. are busy with other projects and not able to expend any effort for the game. It is not clear if and when the devs. will give their attention to the game again as of 29-Nov 2016. I'll keep my rate positive though, because I had a lot of fun with the game and basically it is a good one.---  I came to Shadowrun relatively late only in 2013 when the video game franchise has been rebooted with Shadowrun: Returns. Since then I became a huge fan of the series and played all released PC games so far, including Shadowrun Chronicles: Boston Lockdown.I especially fall for the title made by Cliffhanger Productions due to its online/multiplayer feature. It is a really great experience so far and I must admit that I got addicted a bit recently. Let me summarize Shadowrun Chronicles: Boston Lockdown:It's a classic turn-based strategy (TBS) game like XCOM (as often mentioned), Warhammer 40,000: Chaos Gate or the rebooted Shadowrun game series made by Harebrained Schemes and unifies the best aspects of all mentioned TBS games. Its simple controls and game basics on one hand and its partly very challenging combats and missions on the other hand are in sum appealing to both, 'old hands' and rookies. A bonus are the RPG elements and the skills system, which are similar to Harebrained Schemes' Shadowrun games, but slightly rearranged. Right now, there are already wide possibilities of skills and skill combinations, e.g. decker, rigger, shotguns, blades, blunt, shaman etc.  The game mechanics are based on the fifth edition of the Shadowruns tabletop game and its very potent licence, meaning if you're into cyberpunk, science fiction, dystopia and love the Shadowrun universe, this game is for you.Unfortunately, there are some drawbacks as well. Even though there are relatively much missions to play, lot of them are short or seem kinda inconsistent story wise. In general lacks the story in excitement and depth and gains momentum only late in the story progress. Therefor, some side missions are really interesting and challenging and a lot of fun (but are taking place on recurring maps of the main campaign though). The missions are more fun in cooperative multiplayer with fellow 'Chummers', but sadly it can take quite a while before you get fellow players together since the game is a little depopulated currently. In other words, you are depending on prebuilt henchmen sometimes, whose character development you cannot affect or control. Thus, they are a little 'underpowered' but should be enough powerful for the main story campaign. The interaction with other players is also kinda awkward, since there is no direct chat (whispering) implemented and basically there are only two chatrooms in total existing; the global chat and the party chat if you teamed up with other players. This can be a bit annoying sometimes but is still to handle.Good thing is the developers still add content to the game and have much plans for the future. The support by the game developers, Cliffhanger Productions, is outstanding; very curteous and extremely kindly (and fast!). That's why I rate this game positive. Again: if you're into Shadowrun, TBS and Fantasy, support the devs and that hidden gem and buy it! My judging:3.5/5

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												SRR and its cadre were made by a bigger team with a much-bigger budget and more time to really flex. That being said, while Cliffhangar has worked their asses off and spent many sleepless nights slaving away, having the same expectations for SRC that you have for SRR is going to disappoint you.Does that mean SRC sucks? Not at all. I quite enjoy it, and I invite you to see my profile for the hours I've put into this and the Returns series. If you are a big fan of the Shadowrun lore and universe, I'd be surprised if you didn't like this one.This game does require a perpetual Internet connection, even if you're playing with NPC henchmen. The online aspect of this game is amazing and really helps prevent the "ho hum doing this kind of mission again" burn-out you might feel. We have quite a few character slots so you're free to explore different characters. The cosmetic options are pretty flexible and certainly helps capture the eclectic look of shadowrunners.Unlike SRR this game has voice-acting, although some people cringe at it's B-movie quality. Still though there were a few VA's I enjoyed. However your runner in this game is pretty static. You don't really have control over your personality or dialogue, so you won't feel the same you did in the SRR series.As for the combat, it uses a some-what simpler form of X-Com: EU and SRR. There's still cover (just half and full in this case), but combat itself is very brutal in this game. It's not uncommon for an average runner to only have between 15-23 hp. In fact, end-game runners might just barely clear 40 hp. So if you or an enemy make a mistake, you might very well die from it.Speaking of death, there's really no penalty. If your henchmen dies, oh well. They'll be there next mission, good as new. If a fellow player dies, a timer starts counting down (representing them bleeding to death). If you can't finish the mission in time, you automatically fail. If you do fail a mission, just brush yourself down and try again.Unfortunately, at this time there is no matrix. You have a few times you visit a node to chat with campaign Chummers, but no actual Matrix involved in runs. I'm sure down the line they will implement a more proper form, but for now you're stuck in meat-space. So what the Hell does a decker actually do in SRC then? They use their deck to shoot a dial-up laser of death, which deals a type of damage most enemies are vulnerable to. It also ignores cover and line-of-sight issues. Decking skills can stun or mark enemies, making them easier to hit.At this time the respec option hasn't been completed, so you are stuck with the choices you make for your runner. However the flexibility of your character is still there. You can spec into just about any role you want. Want to be a glass-cannon critting machine? Go for it. Want to hang back and use drones and/or spirits to wade into the fray? Go for it. Want to throw caution into the wind and go melee? Up to you.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
												Ok, so I buy this game while it was in Early Access; played it a few days, took a break from it and then came back. Nothing new, nothing inspiring and nothing to keep me playing it once I beat the initial campaign. Yes there are new weapons, cybergear, etc, but one thing I abhor in a game I've bought is the massive amount of grind time that's required in order to attain higher level stuff. I don't mind it on F2P MMOs, cause that is essentially the nature of those games. This one, however, I paid money to get. Forget that. Not happening. Oh and the DLC: the DLC costs so much more that the game itself. I'm a little bit new to the Shadowrun Franchise. Dragonfall was my first game of the series I bought, then DMS, and then Hong Kong, so I'm not too familiar with the player base nor their affinity towards the franschise itself. However, as a newcomer to the franchise I really believe that this game is one that can be totally bypassed and ignored by other newcomers to the series. This game is nothing like those games and you are better off playing anything else. Literally, anything else: whether it be an online game or single-player game. Just avoid this one.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												Update 04/2015: Since primetide took the time to comment on my review I in turn spent some time on another look at the game and updated my review to reflect the current state of the game. TL;DR: I'll take back that "worst crap" part of my previous review but the thumb will still point down. Sorry.What I liked- Co-op is implemented finally. I never expected it to become a full blown MMORPG. I actually like the online mechanics which are similar to the first guildwars (never played gw2, no clue if it works the same there). Good move to remove "Online" from the title, maybe a bit late ;). I yet have to discover the persitence apsect of the world though. Didn't jump right into my face from the first hours of playing.- Localization is on a good way, there are even localized voiceovers! You would not expect that from an indi game, some tripple-a titles even fail to deliver here.What I did not like- The original Shadowrun game is a roleplaying game with turn based fights as one aspect. Shadowrun Croncicles reduces the whole Shadowrun experience to the round based tactic part of it. "Shadowrun Returns" did a way better job transpoting the SR story/rpg elements to the player by implementing dialog decissions and dialog options based on skills. ShadowRun Chronicles is like what Final Fantasy Tactics was for the Final Fantasy franchise. IMHO it doesn't do the IP justice (although I must admit there have been way worse adoptions in the past *cough* microsoft *cough*). Yes, I AM a demanding customer :P- If a GM on a p&p session would have tossed the amounts of enemies at us like the game does - especially when you are low on level and skills and just started - we would have punched him in the face. From the three runs I did, I didn't manage to finish one without repeating it multiple times and still loosing at least one party member in the end. It often comes down to doing a run at least twice so you know what you got to expect and can manage better / do a better choice on the sidekick you take with you. Not my cup of tea.So while there are some positive aspects - for me the negative ones weight heavier. Overall I'd rahter have skipped buying that game. But since I did and the money is already spent I'll keep having an eye on the game and maybe even the thumb will point up one day if the game emerges from a SR rules based tactics simulator towards an SR roleplaying game.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												Review Update 5/12/15With the lag problem now fixed I wanted to update my review of the game. A more detailed review to come after I have had a chance to put more time into the game.  For now I have changed the recommendation from no to yes, as I am having fun playing the game right now, and Steam doesn't offer any third option yet. The game is fun but flawed. It is a turned-based co-op game with parties between 2-4 characters with an addition 2 summoning slots for drones and spirits. You can fill out the party slots by hiring henchmen that you will control, by finding other people to join you on a mission, or a combination of both.  My experiences with the community have been great, always willing to answer questions I have and I have not had any problems finding people to join me on missions.  Most of flaws in the game come mostly from the game feeling rushed out of Early Access with parts of the game feeling incomplete or unfinished.   One big plus for the game is the Dev's are still working on the game and have been active in the community and seem to be listing to suggestions,  My main problems with the game right now.1. No whisper or private chat in game. There is no way to talk privately to your friends or just to discuss anything with community members.  So have fun filling the global chat with anything you want to talk about. I shouldn't say no way, you can invite them to your group to chat, but that is only if you are not already in a mission and your group isn't full.2. A lack of information in the game. There is a lot of stuff in the game that is never explained to you in game, and a lack of documentation makes some things very frustrating.  Some examples of this are in the perks you choose. Some will clearly start you will receive a 10% increase to damage or critical hits, where as others will only tell you that you will receive a boost to damage or crit, but never how much of a bonus. 3. No looking for group tool or chat. There is no way to find a group to join, or find members for your mission except to keep calling out in the global chat.  4. PVP focus of the game has Cliffhanger making poor design choices.  This game is focused on PVP, which is not even in the game yet, and because of that they have made a number of poor design choices too keep parity in the classes, rather than focus on a good co-op game.  An example of this is Rigger and Decker  have just been turned into magic users with the Rigger being a Shaman that "summons" drones instead of spirits, and the Decker is now a mage that cast "tech" spells to attack the enemy (yes, you read that correctly, Decker magic). The Rigger will also compete with any Shaman on your team for a summon spot, as your team is only allowed to summon 2 things.  -original post-Finally, some real game innovation as Shadowrun Chronicles takes a truly unique approach the the turn-based strategy game. With the introduction of new Lag-based™ gameplay that gives people time to multi-task other activities as they try to find time in their busy schedules to play games.  Do you have a book that you just never got around to reading? Well, Cliffhanger Productions has the solution for you with  Lag-based™ gameplay! Thats right, just issue your command to "walk accross room"  or "examine item" and then take your time to leisurely read a page or two as Shadowrun Chronicles waits to complete your commmand. But wait, theres more!  If you buy right now, you will also get to experience the thrill of the new Never-Sure™ technology. Thats right, as the tension builds as the seconds tick away, you will experience the glory of Never-Sure™ as you think to yourself "maybe this isn't lag, maybe I just didn't click the mouse". Yes, Never-Sure™ technology will have you questioning your sanity at the 20 second mark, and have you convinced at the 30 second mark that this time you really did forget to click the mouse button; but then as if by magic your charicter finaly opens the door and you breath a sigh of relief.  Never-Sure™ technology will ensure each move you make will send you on a rollercoaster ride of emotion; hope, fear, anger, sadness, will all be yours with each command you issue.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												Having enjoyed the other Shadowrun games I got this expecting more of the same.  I was dissapointed to say the least.  When you spend more time picking out your characters underpants than their skills something is wrong.  You have two "Statistics" both of which offer bland variations of combat upgrades and one or two skills that access locked off rooms in a map.  Melee you pick Blades or Blunt, but don't worry they are effectively identical with the only real difference being a bonus against a particular enemy type towards the end of the line.  Yes, line as skills are simply there to give you abilities that use that item.  You have basic proficiency in every skill from the start and the only real gain from putting points into a skill is a shorter cooldown on some abilities.  Ranged you have the greatest variety of options with a whole THREE skills to pick from Pistols, Shotguns, or Automatics.  Magic is reduced to only two options as well with one featuring different ways to summon the same critter and the other containing both direct damage spells in the game.  Tech based skills get the same gutting as everything else with deckers being possibly the furthest deviation from archetype I have ever seen in a game.  Deckers do not jack in or access the Matrix, instead they have been reduced to crippled mages.  Supernatural enemies are immune to tech damage so there is an entire third of them who you cannot effect and you have only a direct damage ability and an aoe with a medium cooldown.  The mission hub is tiny and could have been completely replaced with a post mission debriefing screen where you decide if you want to buy one of the two upgrades you have for your items and then pushes you on to the next mission.  Instead you have a different vendor for weapons, armor, magic and tech and each has between two and nine items total since there are only three variations of any particular weapon and only two options for armor.  Cyberware? nope none for sale.  All in all if you want a bland easy turn based non tactical blast em up to play with a buddy buy this crap on sale, or better yet buy a couple nerf guns and an egg timer you will have more fun.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												This game emulates a recently revived beloved game, but not Shadowrun: Returns. This game feels like XCOM: Enemy Unkown set in the Shadowrun universe except instead of a focus on building your base and squad, it's all about building up your one character. Every mission is heavily combat-focused, there's no dialogue options or speech-skills. Instead the greater focus on combat means missions are built with this in mind with lots of fighting however they're usually quick affairs with longer runs being broken up into several encounters. The game is co-op focused however if you're running solo fear not! The game has a very interesting henchmen system whereby if you are going solo or below the game's (generally) 4-player size requirement, you can place into your team characters made by other players under your control, meaning you can cruise through this game solo if you want.TL:DR - If you want a Shadowrun RPG with a bit more of an XCOM flavour, you've found it. Very good game, 7/10.

												Shadowrun Chronicles is a tactical coop game based on the Shadowrun universe which isn't quite finished yet. But on a very good way.Shadowun Flavor:Yes, this is NOT the Shadowrun from Harebrained Schemes, it's not even like it. This Shadowrun is a different approach, a new interpretation. If you just can stand original works, this is not your game.Developement:This game had its bad days, where it was nearly unplayable. This is quite the past and the devs are making great progress. There is nearly allways some of them in the forums and they do care about the opinions of the players. You can see that they are commited to their product and the players. Content: There is enough content to keep you entertained for some hours. If you want, you can play through it in one or two days. After that it gets a litte bit repeating with running the story. But repeatable missions are in the making and should be soon released.Community:Great guys, not many (yet), but mature. Conclusion:If you like Shadowrun and like tactical games, you want to give this a try.If you are looking for an exact multiplayer copy of Shadowrun Returns, Dragonfall or Hongkong, you will be disappointed.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												Having played Harebrained Studios' excellent Shadowrun Returns and Dragonfall RPGs I came to Chronicles with information like this is an online-only co-op focused game made by another studio and which initially had some pretty terrible reviews that have since improved with the regular patches. Being a single player person I was wondering whether this game would do it for me but after giving it a chance I have to say it is a good game.While Boston Lockdown may not have the full-fledged RPG mechanics of SR and SR:D (favouring a somewhat simpler skill tree) it is a Shadowrun experience with turn-based tactical combat, good 3D - if simple - graphics and - more importantly to me - you can solo the story campaign without problems if you build your character carefully. The story is interesting and there is character building across the campaign. One thing to bear in mind is that multiple aspects of the rich Shadowrun world (which is a long running pen and paper RPG first) are not fully introduced so it would be better if you play another Shadowrun game first to familiarise yourself with the setting so as to fully enjoy it.Of course this being an online co-op-focused game, the game's hub is one relatively small map that acts as a stop-over shopping and discussion location where you will see other players walking around but you can solo the whole thing without problems. As the main story progresses the hub changes to reflect current events and you do get side missions regularly after the introductory missions are over. The only thing preventing this being a serviceable offline SR game is the always online requirement (saves are server side) and the small easy to ignore chat window on the bottom left. As the developers do not have the rights to make an offline game this is an understandable compromise but I do hope it gets a full offline mode sometime in the future so the game lives on past the servers. The difficulty especially in the beginning is quite high which makes for an interesting challenge and pushes you to plan and execute carefully.So TL;DR: Yes, this is a good Shadowrun game for single player types and scratches that turn based Shadowrun itch in between the Harebrained studios core entries.
